div.p: This element is found in BIOGRAPHY CULTURALFORMATION . It is sometimes within CLASSISSUE. Unlike CLASSISSUE, which contains detailed discussion of her class position, CLASS is meant to capture an identifying word or phrase. From this element users can generate lists of women writers who were working-class or aristocratic or whatever. It has optional attributes: Self-defined and SOCIALRANK. The latter offers a range of values, allowing you to express class in a standard way.

div.codeblock: JB was born into a <CLASS SOCIALRANK="gentry">propertied</CLASS> family.

MM grew up in a <CLASS SOCIALRANK="professional">"landowning, parliamentary"</CLASS> family, but was faced with financial difficulties once she <CLASS SOCIALRANK="gentry">inherited her father's estate</CLASS> along with its heavy debts.

div.p: The structured vocabulary to be used for CLASS and SOCIALRANK is imperfect. Try to use the term that best suits your writer. Use multiple times if her class position shifted throughout her life. Include a SOCIALRANK attribute if you can. When there is much doubt around this classification, say so in the prose, and consider using the CLASSISSUE tag.
